Dialogue.Student: Hi, I'm Oliver Martinez. This is my first time here.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Oliver! It’s great to meet you. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m feeling a mix of excitement and anxiety about the new semester.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s completely normal! Starting a new semester can be quite overwhelming at times. What are some of the things that are causing you anxiety?
Dialogue.Student: I’m taking on a lot this semester—my psychology classes are demanding, and I’m also leading a couple of volunteer projects.
Dialogue.Counselor: It sounds like you have a full plate! Have you had a chance to talk to anyone about how you're feeling?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I’m a bit embarrassed to say that I’m struggling.
Dialogue.Counselor: There’s no need to feel embarrassed. Many students face similar challenges. Would you like to explore ways to better manage your responsibilities?

Dialogue.Student: Hi again. I’m feeling more stressed this week.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi, Oliver! I’m glad you came back. What’s been going on this week?
Dialogue.Student: I just can’t seem to catch a break. I’m worried about meeting all my deadlines, and I’ve been irritable with my friends and family.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds really tough. It can be hard to balance everything. Are you feeling like you can connect with your friends, especially your sister Sofia?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I feel guilty for not being there for her like I used to. I just can’t find the energy.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s understandable to feel that way under pressure. It’s okay to prioritize taking care of yourself. Have you thought about what you might do to address these feelings with her?

Dialogue.Student: Hello, I had a really hard time this week.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi, Oliver! I’m sorry to hear that. What happened?
Dialogue.Student: I had a breakdown after a volunteer event when my friend Jake confronted me about not being around lately.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds really intense. How did that conversation make you feel?
Dialogue.Student: I felt attacked at first but then I realized I was just shutting everyone out. I haven’t been managing my responsibilities well.
Dialogue.Counselor: Acknowledging that can be a difficult step. Do you feel like you’re able to express these feelings to Jake?
Dialogue.Student: I didn’t, and now I feel regretful for not being open. I’m worried this will affect our friendship.
Dialogue.Counselor: It's completely normal to fear how others will perceive you, but sharing your feelings could actually strengthen your friendship. Have you thought about reaching out to him?

Dialogue.Student: Hi! I finally talked to Jake, and it helped. I apologized for shutting him out.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s wonderful to hear, Oliver! How did that conversation go?
Dialogue.Student: It was really good. I opened up about the pressure I’ve been feeling, and he was really supportive.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s fantastic! It sounds like you found some relief in being honest. What did he suggest?
Dialogue.Student: He offered to help with the volunteer projects and get back on track together. I feel relieved, but I’m still anxious about balancing everything.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s understandable. It’s okay to still feel some anxiety. Just take it one step at a time and remember to lean on your support system when you need it.
Dialogue.Student: Thanks for your advice. I really appreciate it!
Dialogue.Counselor: You’re welcome! I’m here to help. Don’t hesitate to check in again if you need to talk.
